keyTakeAways: A runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run.
The attack resulted in severe injuries: a broken arm and claw punctures on his leg, requiring three surgeries including a hip graft and metal plates.
Bear attacks have increased in Japan due to climate change disrupting natural food sources, prompting bears to venture into urban and rural areas.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the rising incidents.
Residents use methods such as carrying bells or playing loud music to deter bears, and Halloran now suggests carrying bear spray as a precaution.
Halloran, despite trauma and recovery challenges, remains committed to returning to running and engaging with nature, citing support from the local running community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears during a routine run in the woods near Myoko, Japan. The attack caused severe injuries, including a broken arm and leg wounds requiring multiple surgeries. This incident is part of a growing trend of bear attacks in Japan, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year, linked to climate change disrupting bears’ traditional food sources and forcing them into human habitats. In response, the Japanese government has announced tougher bear control measures. Residents are advised to use deterrents like bear spray or loud sounds, and Halloran, despite trauma and long-term recovery, remains determined to return to running and nature, highlighting both personal resilience and the broader environmental crisis.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
